page.title: 08WILDLIFE, SOUTH FEN/TWENTY
page.content: In an area almost{devoid of human } {habitation}wildlife in every form abounds, from the road-side{flowers}to the{mammals}in the fields, the{birds } in the (limited) hedgerows and{fish}in the rivers and dykes. Some of the more common flowers include cowslip, primrose, rose-bay willow herb, poppy, campions, iris, ragged-robin and rock-rose. In addition to members of the mouse family, rabbits and hares are very common and a fox may often be seen hunting for food. Swan, moorhen and coot nest near the river where herons are often seen. The lapwing, skylark and swallow are very common as are most members of the thrush and finch families,whilst owls, kestrel and harrier quarter the area. A wide variety of fish are to be found in the rivers and dykes.
